title: Inflammatory Breast Cancer with Skin Changes
setup_script: A 45-year-old woman presents with rapidly enlarging left breast with erythema, edema, and peau d'orange for two weeks. She has no fever. Palpable axillary lymph nodes are present. Biopsy confirms invasive ductal carcinoma with dermal lymphatic invasion.

dynamic_flow.trigger: Recognize clinical presentation of inflammatory breast cancer (IBC) and differentiate from mastitis.
Order diagnostic imaging: bilateral mammogram, ultrasound, and breast MRI to assess extent; stage with CT chest/abdomen/pelvis and bone scan.
Perform core needle biopsy of breast lesion and fine-needle aspiration of axillary nodes; confirm diagnosis histologically.
Discuss aggressive nature of IBC and poor prognosis without treatment; emphasize need for multidisciplinary care.
Plan neoadjuvant systemic therapy (chemotherapy with anti-HER2 agents if HER2 positive) followed by modified radical mastectomy.
Refer to medical oncology for staging and initiation of chemotherapy; manage treatment side effects.
Monitor response to therapy with clinical exams and imaging; adjust regimen if inadequate response.
After completion of chemotherapy, plan modified radical mastectomy with axillary lymph node dissection; discuss reconstruction options.
Perform surgery; ensure clear margins; send specimens for pathology to assess response (pathologic complete response).
Postoperative care: manage drains, wound, and discuss need for adjuvant radiation therapy to chest wall and regional nodes.
Continue systemic therapy (HER2 targeted agents, endocrine therapy) as indicated; refer to radiation oncology.
Provide psychosocial support and counseling on prognosis, fertility preservation, and survivorship.

critical_decision_points: Early recognition of inflammatory breast cancer and avoidance of delay with antibiotics.
Appropriate staging and initiation of neoadjuvant chemotherapy.
Timing of surgery after systemic therapy and extent of axillary surgery.
Coordination of adjuvant radiation and systemic therapy.
Comprehensive patient counseling and psychosocial support.
